This was a really cute anime.  The interpersonal relationships are very well done and the characters are interesting in their own individual ways.  The artwork is absolutely stunning.  They do a good job of drawing the viewer into the gravitas of the high school drama, without overstating it or going over-the-top, a la Strawberry Panic (which is awesome).  Overall the show was quite enjoyable and I have few complaints or criticisms.
That said, I was put off a bit by Maki-kun's character introduction, as it really gave me this dangerous and perverted feel from him which is not at all whatthe authors intended and which doesn't play out in the show.  They attempted to make him seem nonthreatening but the intensity they put behind his feelings makes it difficult for the viewer to initially catch what's going on.  Also, Yuu's character was often quizzical, and her personal motivations consistently elude me, which I do not think is the intention of the author.  I also feel like Nanami's root motivation is strangely unquestioned; realistically even high school kids wouldn't hear something like that and be like "Oh well I guess that's a cool life goal to have", especially to a friend.  Which once again adds to the quizzical quality of Yuu's personality, as it seems to me like even as just a friend she should be fighting against that idea.  A lot of times it feels like the words being said don't really mean anything, especially in romantic conversations, because so much is unspoken.  This is good in that it's how romance should be written, but also bad in that the nonsense words they speak over their actions really muddle any implied emotional tells of the characters, and just left me kind of confused at times.\n\n
All that said, I still think this is a spectacular anime, and a wonderful example of high school romance.  There was no point throughout the series where I felt bored or less than excited for more, and even the less-consequential characters seemed realistic and deeply-written.\n\n
I'd recommend this to anyone who has a soft spot for yuri, likes melodramatic high school romances, or who likes realistic anime with a strong focus on character development.

First of all, I shall apologize for not reading the source material just yet; this review is purely based on what I've experienced with the anime. Also, this is completely spoiler free, so is extremely suggestive and perhaps intuitive. I won't even include summary, since is better to preserve one of the good aspects of the show: surprise.
Yagate Kimi ni Naru; Bloom Into You; Eventually, I Will Become You... the title fits perfectly, because this is a story about grasping into memories, perceiving thyself and mostly expressing characters identities as they progress with their own perception about themselves, about how others perceive them and abouthow they perceive the world and the ones interacting with them.


At first it may not seem like it, since it goes slowly building those aspects into proper development. But even though it may appear that romance is what this story is all about, love is solely the thread that guides the characters through their own identity, and as they perceive love they express what existence really is, and how they should particularly interact with themselves and the world. Subjectivity is indeed a big keyword here.


Storywise, the plot is focused on Touko Nanami, a second year high school student and member of the student council. But the way the story is told is very particular, since we have the opportunity to glimpse at each of the characters perceptions about Nanami, especially the first year high school student, Nanami's kouhai, Yuu Koito. This is a very intelligent approach, and probably one of the best things about the anime, since it gives the viewer the opportunity to think about what they're watching and receiving, as each of the characters perception differs from one to another, and you never really get all the answers. But don't worry; all you have to do is let yourself follow the pace, because the anime manages to convey all of those messages and perceptions in subtle facial expressions, environment dynamics, sound execution and smart direction choices.


The art is really beautiful and fits perfectly with the general aura of the show, expressing the wholesome idea of the universe the characters live in, at the same time with all the heavy sorrowfulness of the depths of consciousness, self-perception and the pain of growing up and learning how to choose, how to live, how to perceive, how to love and how to be alive.


I could say the music is scarce, but the sound is always there, lingering through the environment. Sometimes it's really quiet and all we have is how the characters interact with each other, while portraying in specific behavior settings. Everything about the sound direction is really good and gives you the feeling of being inside the story, capturing each moment with dazzling melody. But then, all of sudden, the music arises and is too late; you're catch off guard and simply emerge with its wonderful tones.


In the end, the way the characters are depicted really is the strong aspect of Yagate Kimi ni Naru. As I said previously, love is the thread that guides them through their own perception and to development itself, and with it the identity of each one of them represents unfathomable horizons, always preserving a subtle realism that builds up slowly and steady.


Overall is a great anime, a fine piece of art, which shines through the depths of real, innermost and everyday life. I won't give it a 10 because unfortunately the story has not ended yet, so as far as progression and development goes, you still are left unfinished, with a feeling of wholesome, yet bitter and depressing affection. Notwithstanding, I might say it really is a masterpiece after all, since it conveys so much in so simple and subtle exposition. Bloom Into You is one of those things that really makes you proud to be an anime fan.

"Yagate Kimi ni Naru" is a shoujo-ai school romance anime. And that's it. In relation to the story, it is not much different from a typical anime. It uses much of the shoujo-ai cliches popularized from "Oniisama e" (and that exist in non-lesbian school romances). The (principal) scenario is a school, the protagonist is an innocent new student (Yuu), meets a senpai (Touko), feelings begin to emerge, and one of the two has a friend (Sayaka) who may or may not represent an obstacle to the two staying together in some way. All this while dealing with your school routines that usually do not haveanything very interesting. And like many modern anime, here we have a season that doesn't completely close the story.


But then it's a bad anime? No. At first it seems to be because the way a certain feeling between Yuu and Touko arises is quite sudden. But it's not sudden in the sense of "love at first sight," just suddenly enough to look and wonder what exactly made it start. It was not a plausible start. But the anime is not too daring or sexy to please a male audience or perverted girls. It is even subtle at times, and despite having rushed to make a mood come up between the characters, he recognizes that they have their moral senses and contexts that prevent them from wanting to date at the moment. But a good romance anime is not only about that, but also about how the characters deal with each other, and whether there is a psychological justification for them to be the way they are. And it is especially the case of Touko. Your personality, way of relating to people and desires has motives. Other characters are not so rich in these quests and the most interesting is to see how they act with Touko being the way it is or shows itself to be. Most of the time we see things from Yuu's point of view, and it is interesting to see how it deals with Touko's "true self." In addition, Yuu's quest to understand herself, her identity, and her attempt to form her opinion about love also make her an interesting character, though not as well-characterized as Touko. But it's a good representation of a teenage girl. I also like the fact that the anime has almost no comedy, since most of the school anime and yuri are in excess and are rarely well used.


Yuu's alleged rivalry with Sayaka (Touko's best friend at first) is not interesting and seems almost non-existent, but Sayaka at least is not a bad girl, and there's something interesting about her past. But one problem with the cast is that sometimes they seem to think that there is something absurd in a lesbian relationship, but it seems to be something without justification and that it exists only for no couple to be officially signed. The rest of the cast isn't good, but I saw potential in Seji for the metaphorical form as the direction of the anime showed his interest in observing couples' lives (I'm naive to expect anything from a male character in a yuri). Most dialogues on school subjects are tedious, though necessary to develop the relationships between the main female characters.


Visually the anime is nothing special, but it's good. The animation works, although it does not have so much fluidity or detailed character designs (I think it's even better for this type of story that the characters' visuals are simple). Like the anime sometimes uses certain visual metaphors to express the thoughts of the characters, as well as some tricks of direction like sometimes to use some angle where we do not see the eyes of a character, to the facial expression of being "ambiguous". The soundtrack and voice acting are nothing special, but neither was a bad job done. The most noticeable thing is the opening.


In general, what can be said is that it is a simple anime without much story, but with two interesting characters dealing with adolescence experiences and discovering more about who they are, without the drama being interrupted by much sexual fanservice or stupid humor. If it was not in the terrible 1-cour format, had more character development, or was good since the first few episodes, I would have appreciated more it would be a 7/10. But unlike what most users of MAL think, SIX IS ALREADY A NOTE ABOVE THE AVERAGE! And Yagate Kimi ni Naru was easily one of the best anime of the deplorable year 2018.

Antes de eu dizer o que sinto sobre este anime fantástico, como esta é a primeira vez, quero apenas informar que as minhas reviews vão ser sempre em português e que como é óbvio qualquer um que entenda é bem-vindo. Sem mais delongas passando então à review em si:
História/Plot (8/10)
Yagate Kimi ni Naru, também conhecido como Bloom Into You, é claramente uma história feita para todo o tipo de idades, sem grandes temas pesados ou que causem desconforto a quem assiste (istoé se não houver preconceito com Shoujo Ai). Nunca tenta apresentar algo a que não se comprometeu, tem uma escrita simples mas que ao mesmo tempo consegue passar uma profundidade enorme com temas "clichês" como o romance e o desenvolvimento pessoal através do mesmo.

Sendo honesto, não sou o maior fã de animes Shoujo Ai e até agora nunca nenhum me tinha cativado mas Yagate conseguiu fazer isso. Com o seu charme inocente e ao mesmo tempo maduro, transmitiu algo que a maioria dos animes de romance falham em conseguir.


Arte, Direção & Sound (9/10)


O estúdio TROYCA com certeza não é dos mais influentes na indústria da animação nem nunca apresentou um grande hit que fosse falado por várias pessoas mas mesmo andando sempre nas "sombras" dos grandes nomes, o estúdio tem uma política que eu gosto, poucos animes mas que visualmente costumam ter uma qualidade muito boa principalmente se eles forem dirigidos pelo Makoto, que na minha opinião, é o melhor diretor de lá.

Yagate nesse quesito é muito interessante, todos os cenários e certos cortes de animação corporal têm um tratamento especial, a paleta de cores entra em harmonia com o ambiente e consegue proporcionar cenários que, embora simples, neste contexto elevam-se para um patamar superior.

A direção do Katou Makoto tem sofrido ao longo dos anos uma melhoria muito positiva e que cada vez mais te deixa com vontade de assistir algo dirigido por ele.

A parte sonora tanto a atuação dos seiyuus quanto a soundtrack é muito boa e encaixa perfeitamente com o clima do anime, de realçar a Kotobuki Minako que consegue elevar qualquer personagem a um nível estonteante com a sua capacidade de passar os sentimentos na hora certa e de forma, às vezes, imprevisível.


Personagens (9/10) 


É neste território que Yagate brilha, cada personagem tem uma individualidade especial mas que ao mesmo tempo é algo que conseguimos relacionar com a nossa vida ou de pessoas próximas.

A Touko e a Yuu sofrem do mesmo problema, nunca terem conseguido se apaixonar de verdade, mas o que mais me impressiona é como o mesmo problema consegue criar 2 personagens tão distintas e com abordagens diferentes. Como sempre é muito gratificante ver que no fim de 13 episódios existe uma evolução nas suas maneiras de pensar e até mesmo como aprendem a amar e a superar o problema que no final das contas, as juntou.

Acho importante referir que a autora sempre tenta mostrar personagens que não dividem do mesmo tipo de relação das nossas Yuu e Touko, o que torna uma história muito mais credível e não um sítio onde todas se sentem da mesma maneira, mecanismo que apenas serve para criar um drama forçado. Isto tudo ao contrário duma certa obra que acabou por ficar mais famosa, infelizmente.


Enjoyment (9.5/10)


Não me vou alongar aqui apenas que me diverti todas as semanas e fiquei sempre com vontade de ver o próximo episódio e ver como todo o plot evoluiría. Tudo que disse em cima aplica-se aqui.


Overall (9/10)

I'm a fan.
Yagate Kimi ni Naru is very good slice of life, a slow-moving and beautiful picture of high school romance and growing up wrapped into a portrait of wide-ranging LGBT issues. By LGBT issues I mean quite a lot-- lesbians kissing, of course, but also bisexuality, repression/"phases", and asexuality. That last one's the big one.
Protagonist Yuu is rather unique in that she is very much gray in her own sexuality, finding it difficult to feel the same love that her senpai Touko gives onto her. Asexual/aromantic characters are almost entirely unrepresented in fiction, and the fact that Yuu is the central focus here ispretty incredible. It's not a POV we see often in anime, let alone in a show already embroiled in LGBT romance. 


And to say that the show is primarily about Yuu and Touko's romantic relationship is a mighty understatement; almost every single bit of the series is dedicated to the two characters discovering and learning to love each other, and in turn learning to love themselves. A lot of the plot beats here are familiar for anyone who's read a shoujo manga; the drama is pretty predictable, with doomed love triangles and sad backstories and school life troubles, but the show is able to move past that on the strength of these two characters.


The show revels in subtlety and visual storytelling. While the animation is alright, the "cinematography" is fantastic, using film techniques like close ups, POV shots, cutaways, interesting camera angles, the kinds of stuff you don't see often in anime, all to show the characters' emotions without actually spelling it out directly. Yuu learning to love Touko is a long, gradual process, and doesn't take form in a specific moment but throughout the series, and never with any dramatic revelation. Just some eyes fluttering, some long stares, and some beautiful glowing scenery. I'd call it a general "softness."


Yeah, that probably sums up the series as a whole. Very soft.


Once again, the anime does nothing revolutionary outside of the typical Shoujo confines-- you've got a lot of internal monologuing, a quirky side cast, some obligatory makeouts and a sex scene that cuts from the actual sex-- but it is a well-refined work and its exploration into asexuality is really nice. The extreme frankness with which Yuu and Touko discuss their feelings (or lack thereof) for each other is also refreshing. So many good moments come from them actually communicating and being open with one another.


Though, I do gotta mention that Touko, mostly in the earlier episodes, is pushy on a level that veers towards breaking consent, and that isn't a nice thing at all. Yuu eventually chews her out, but there are a couple uncomfortable moments before the two finally settle on themselves, and I don't think the issue was addressed as firmly as it needed to be because pushiness and dubious consent is a sadly common occurrence in LGBT anime of all genres. Every romantic moment in the second half of the show is pretty firmly consensual though, in a nice way.


My biggest problem with the show? It doesn't friggin' end! The last episode cuts off with something of a character moment between Yuu and Touko, one that essentially solidifies everything that came before it, but there is no climax and no resolution, as if we are just supposed to wait for the second season now. Which is real lame, guys. Give us a real season finale even if the continuation is inevitable. Because sometimes inevitable continuations don't actually end up working out that way... (Gakkou Gurashi RIP) I will genuinely lower this to a 5 if there isn't a second season in the end, because of how much this show leaves things dangling. Don't do that.


Don't watch this show if you're looking for a bunch of fanservicey heavy petting and any super dramatic moments. Because you ain't gonna get that with Yagate Kimi ni Naru. Watch this for some really good characters, really good discussions of LGBT issues, and some really doki doki romantic moments.

Yagate Kimi ni Naru (Bloom Into You) takes a fairly simple premise of unrequited love and adds some unique complexity: our main character is the recipient of these feelings from a popular girl, but feels that she is aromantic. While additional complications come later, what Bloom Into You really uses to spread this conflict across thirteen episodes is a carefully crafted tension that bleeds into every scene.
Watching the story from the perspective of the object of these unrequited feelings is surprisingly refreshing. Usually, and especially in anime, a protagonist only finds themselves in this position simply because they are oblivious to the feelings of theother or because they love somebody else. Bloom Into You eschews these tropes with Yuu displaying an aromantic and/or asexual inability to feel attraction. It is worth noting that they never explicitly use these terms, and instead describe it quite touchingly. Yuu really wishes she could feel the same things everyone around her, but doesn't force herself play the part. It is also worth making the disclaimer that Maki, someone who claims the same aromantic incapabilities as Yuu says fairly early on that he doesn't believe she is truly like him. This allows the wondering of whether or not she will ever be able to feel romantic love contribute to the underlying tension of Bloom Into You. 

There is something strangely relatable about the isolation Yuu feels as a result of her inability to reciprocate feelings, as it appeals to any viewer who has felt that life, as depicted in the love songs and romantic stories that make up so much of our cultures, was passing them by.


Touko Nanami is an intriguing character from the start. and her facade seems recognisable even before it is revealed. I felt that her determined effort to emulate her deceased sister would work better if she were not as self aware of it, as her internal monologue can sometimes make it sound a bit more simple than it really is. Nonetheless, it is a compelling endeavour to watch, particularly after she drops the act for the first time around Yuu, and it adds a certain meaningful sadness to all scenes where she appears to be a confident student council president in front of others.


If Saeki Sayaka is meant to be as likeable as the two leads, then she feels slightly underdeveloped. Her revealed feelings for Nanami add a lot of suspense to the narrative, due to the times she is deliberately positioned as an obstruction to the flagship relationship. This seems strange when contrasted with scenes that garner empathy for her own unrequited feelings, leaving one unsure of her role.


Bloom Into You is at its strongest when Yuu and Nanami find themselves alone. At times, these scenes are absolutely overflowing with suspense - the timing and careful choosing of every word and movement contribute to a perfect recreation of heart-pounding high school romance. Alternatively, these scenes can be relaxed and comfortable, giving a feeling that the two are undeniably meant to be.


Another master stroke of Bloom Into You is the student council theatre performance. It is used as a microcosm of the overarching story itself, explainable by the fact that the observant Koyomi wrote it to match the student council members. Having the complications of Nanami's identity reflected in the play serves to bring a deeper understanding to her struggle.


There's an emotional intelligence and maturity that Bloom Into You impressively upholds. Sympathetic descriptions of how someone feels (or doesn't) are used well, and in lieu of labels. Characters can also be hard to read at times because the show does not rely on over expressive caricatures, utilising subtext and impressive dialogue instead. As someone who is heterosexual, representation is not something I have ever had to consider, but I would like to think Bloom Into You does a great job with its depictions, especially the glances at the relationship between Riko Hakozaki and Miyako Kodama.


The final episode being anticlimactic will work against Bloom Into You if there is no sequel, but I understand that the manga is still ongoing and hopes are in place for a sequel to this season, therefore the lack of resolution to the tension that Bloom Into You masterfully commands can be mitigated. It's somewhat nice that the series does not culminate with a changing of who someone is (despite Maki's observation being an out in this regard for Yuu, and more debatably Yuu's gradually changing participation in Nanami's 'indulgence'). Rather, we are presented with characters becoming more comfortable with who they are individually, and Yuu and Nanami enjoying their unusual relationship for what it is. I hope that viewers can share this enjoyment, but I entirely understand anyone feeling let down, because I too am left hoping to see more closure to Nanami's struggles of identity in a possible follow-up.

Bloom Into You is probably the best yuri anime produced to date, even though it's not really the romance tale you might expect it to be and it can be, in my opinion, quite painful to watch from an emotional standpoint. It starts with Yuu, a girl who cannot feel love and more or less resigned herself to the thought she'll never find it, catching the attention of Nanami, the seemingly-perfect president of the student council. The actual focus of the story, however, is Nanami's internal struggle - the trauma of losing her beloved sister and the self-destructive drive to become a perfect replacement forher, to "bloom" into being her, which is what the title references. Yuu, the only person who really understands Nanami and the only one the president allowed close enough to learn her true feelings, has to find a way to help her find her own path, while possibly also getting more in touch with her own feelings.


The drama in the series is actually pretty low-key, but the emotional weight of Nanami's struggle and the way she manipulates people around here to achieve her goals are rather heavy. Some people see this series as slow-paced and relaxing, but I actually found it quite excruciating - never because of cheap melodrama or edgy plot devises, but exactly because of how convincing and emotional the whole scenario was. Also, while the main couple is already quite interesting and unusual, the supporting cast is similarly excellent, having both a decent amount of depth and meaningful roles within the story (particularly the council vice-president, Sayaka, who's clearly in love with Nanami). Even the general approach to lesbian romance is fairly serious and realistic, not placing the story in some kind of "yuritopia" where everyone's gay and happy about it, but very subtly signalizing the internal struggles and societal scorn connected to being a homosexual.


The visual and sound quality are top-notch, just as you'd hope from this kind of series. Nothing in it really left me many reasons to complain - despite the anxiety-inducing story developments and Nanami's relentless emotional self-harm, it was a fascinating watch and easily surpassed any other yuri drama I've seen in anime form (nothing beats yuri visual novels, but that's beside the point). I just have to warn any potential reader that while the show has its share of romantic moments, kisses etc., the romance part is far from being conclusive. It ends on a very positive and hopeful note, but leaving a lot to watcher's imagination, so if you're looking for a romance above anything else, it might not satisfy you. Other than that, I think it's a great series and something definitely worth watching, not just for yuri fans, but anyone looking for a good drama VN.

What is the essence of a good romance story? What makes it tick?
It's a well-trod genre, one of the oldest and most trafficked, probably dating back to before humans even had written language, back when we all gathered 'round the fireside and told tales.  And it's easily defined: If a story's primary topic is romantic love, it's a love story, or a romance, or however you'd prefer to describe it.
But I believe that whenever you use a genre to tell a story, that story should justify occupying its place within the genre. In other words, a romance story should be a story which couldonly be told as a romance story.  That might seem easy and obvious, but it's not necessarily so; many's a tale where the relationship is only held apart by obstacles which really have nothing to do with love.  The romance becomes a McGuffin, a goal to be achieved but not the subject of the journey itself.


Not so for Bloom Into You.  It is emphatically a love story; the topic is love and romance, and the story's conflicts are internal to the characters, and have to do with their relationship with each other, and more importantly, to themselves and to love generally.  And although it's marketed as Yuri, its themes are universal and personal.


If you can't tell already by my long-winded introduction to this review, I seriously enjoyed Bloom Into You.


So, beyond being a real, honest-to-goodness romance, what's there to like about this series?


The first thing that grabbed me was the tone.  It's serious, mature, and even grave at times.  If you're looking for comedy, you're looking in the wrong place.  But for all that Bloom Into You is serious, it handles itself well, without falling into cringey dialogue or overwrought emotion.


The second thing I loved was the reversal of some iconic tropes.  In a typical high school romance, the main character falls in love with somebody else, and isn't sure whether their feelings are returned; in Bloom Into You, that premise is inverted: the main character is confessed to early on, but feels nothing in return.  And yet her eagerness to please others and her loneliness keep her engaged in the situation, and--we're off.  Prepare for some real, deep character work, and even further inversions on the expected, which I won't spoil here.


And yes, Bloom Into You deals heavily in character and identity.  Gradual evolution is the name of the game, as the characters change and learn more about each other.


The only unfortunate thing is that this is very clearly half a story.  We get evolution, but we don't get revolution; there's no catharsis here, no climactic conclusion, and no answer to the central questions that are posed.  For that, we'll have to wait for season 2, or the ending of the manga, I suppose.


The animation is also merely adequate.  The character designs are easily identifiable, if a little plain, and the background art is fine, but there are many shots where the animation is minimal to cut costs.  It's not an ugly anime by any means, but it's rarely beautiful, either.


On the plus side, this is a series with almost no fan service or slapstick humor whatsoever, allowing you to relax and enjoy the excellent writing.  And there are some interesting stylistic choices in the animation, too, such as the occasional use of first person perspective.


And the voice acting and music really make a big difference, as well--both impeccable and perfectly suited to the story.


But when it comes down to it, you're here for the characters and for the writing.  Both are excellent, some of the best I've had the pleasure of experiencing in this genre.  If you have any interest in the premise whatsoever, watch this show, and cross your fingers for a second season.  9/10.

When she eventually reciprocates Touko's feelings she never states it outright through the typical anime inner monologue, but it's still made extremely obvious. The Big Gay Elephant in the Room: 2/10

It's extremely obvious that the main reason someone would want to watch this show is for the lesbian romance—just look at the cover art for this series and it's hella gay. There's also a lesbian love confession in the first episode, a lesbian kiss in the second episode, and if you can tell by my character ratings, pretty much all of the main characters fall under the LGBT spectrum or ace umbrella. These characters all feel like they were written by someone who's actually part of the LGBT community and not some straight person fetishizing yuri or something gross like that. So it's extremely disappointing that this show refuses to deliver on its main romance. 


The first six episodes made me uneasy because I kept worrying it would pull The Bad Anime Thing and just go, "LOL nevermind it's not gay!" Episode seven made it seem they weren't going to do that, but then every episode after that just became the typical anime shiptease where nothing gets resolved. By episode nine I was already sick of it and just wanted them to get together already. By episode eleven I wanted Yuu to smack Touko upside the head and deliver this exact line: "Touko, I'm in love with you, you fucking idiot. Stop being a self-hating edge lord and let yourself be loved already." Episode thirteen is the worst offender of the shiptease, with heavy buildup toward Yuu finally confessing to Touko only to just... not do it. And trust me, there is A LOT of buildup, to the point where there's an after-credits scene that almost feels like a "gotcha" that's finally going to deliver only to chicken out for the umpteenth time in the same episode.


Yeah yeah, I know Yuu's final line, "Touko, it's time to change trains" was supposed to be symbolic or whatever, but I'm going to say it again: LGBT romance doesn't need this vague, pussyfooting nonsense. If you're going to write an ambiguous, "subtle" romance with that stupid You'll Never Know if They Actually Get Together Ending, at least have the decency to make it straight; straight folks aren't starved for good content, but LGBT folks ARE. If you're going to write an LGBT romance, either make it explicit and definitive, or GTFO.

When Troyca was announced to be in charge of this adaptation, several alarm bells sounded in my head. The studio behind such trashfires such as Aldnoah Zero and Re:Creators doing a slice of life yuri with light drama? And to top that off with a really ugly promotional poster that really emphasized the chin sharpness of the two mains, looking nothing like Nakatani's art. Miraculously, Yagate Kimi ni Naru is not only the most visually stunning show of the season, thanks to it's impeccable direction and strong source material, but also one of my personal favourites of the season. 
It's just a very relaxing show.Whatever light drama in it is just enough to make me want to watch future episodes without making me bored after each episode ends. Takada Yuuki's portrayal of Yuu is simply perfect, there's the innocence and emotionless tone to her voice that's subtle yet adds to Yuu's overall character so much. It's one of those cases where a seiyuu's performance truly makes the work what it is and elevates it to something truly spectacular. Yuu's interactions with Touko are a joy to watch. It's a nice blend of comfy with just that little bit of drama to keep things moving. 


The music too. By God does it really complement each scene well. The composition has a real fairytale vibe to it, which actually reminds me of a less mischievous Little Witch Academia score. It does suit a more fantastical show, but is no less effective there than it is here. The piano leitmotif punctuates important scenes well, and it's a tune you can't get out of your head. It's the perfect soundtrack to listen to on a nice gentle afternoon.


Speaking of gentle, I just love how gentle the color palette and overall visuals of the show are. It all adds to the comfy, relaxing nature of the show, but can get vivid and striking when it needs to. The promotional poster was thankfully a fluke, but I wish it wasn't used as the album cover for the official soundtrack. Kinda dampens the whole thing. 


My one gripe is how short it all felt. This really should've been 2-cour, with all that buildup to the Seitokai Drama Show all being for nothing if they're not gonna adapt it, as with how almost nothing gets resolved, and how character development for both mains only really just went past the first checkpoint, still far from the finish line. 


Oh well, one can only dream of a Season 2. Just reading the manga without the excellent music, the smooth voices, and of course, that brilliant direction feels so empty somehow.

Hi! Welcome to another of Robert's Too Late Reviews! This time we have an interesting title, one that I'm so very glad I came across. I will say up front that I do tend to write my reviews as 'blind' as possible, skimming overall scores and perhaps first lines of a few reviews to see if I think a series is going to be worth my time. Having done that with Yagate Kimi ni Naru I saw a few different statements saying how this is a story of self realization and of love and personal growth. I will say now that I too agree onthis general theme, so this is going to be my own personal spin on that view. Considering my overall score, I wholeheartedly recommend this anime series, especially if character driven storytelling is something you enjoy. As for the RTLR wall of kissy faces, I'm guessing you can already tell how that's going to go. Nevertheless, we're off!


Story (and partial Character): 9

To start with the less stellar issues involved in the story section, I must say that this is a bit of a slow burn. Now we do have some immediate love proclamations and a bit of kissing early, but the true heart of the show, the true stylings come much later into the tale. We first have to learn about who the characters are from the opening point of view to gain the understanding needed for the existential questioning that comes towards the end. Before we realize that the characters are having such personal issues, it can seem a little on the slow side. To me, it reminded me of my most beloved Maria-sama ga Miteru which also started slow before pushing hard as it progressed towards the end of the first season. In fact, if you are a Marimite fan like me, then just go watch this one, you'll love it I promise. But back on point, we have a bit of slower progression than many other series which does require a small amount of dedication to stay with, but the payoff is more than worth it. 


The other main issue I had story wise was the main character Yuu holding so hard to her mantra of not knowing how being in love feels, even long after it was more than apparent she had fallen for her senpai. I understand that is part of her story arc, but the decision to have her still think she's above love even when showing it with her actions is a writing choice I personally would not have made. Her admitting she was falling would have not broken her character, I think. 


Now the meat. The story really is about who we are, or who we think we are. When we are faced with perspectives on ourselves that refute or challenge our self imagine, what do we do? How do we respond? How do we determine what is important, what we want to live for? No matter the answers to these questions, there is growth. Sometimes it can be negative, but in this case, it's primarily positive. Our aforementioned senpai can easily be considered our co-main character, and her growth is driven by what appears at first to be just an overwhelming desire for excellence, as we see in so many overachiever type people, but in the end we find out she has a deep, painful reason for being who she is trying to be.


Therein also lies a major plot point. Should she try to be someone else? Is she failing herself by trying to honor another? Has she lost sight of who she really is in her quest to live the life she does for the reasons she has? And what about the feelings sparked by Yuu? She develops a near instant romance with the underclassman, but yet does not want to see Yuu return her love. She seems sometimes to have picked Yuu precisely because she is unlikely to return her affections. But is that the way she should live her life? Why would she make that choice? All these questions and more drive the story forward, and the answers can be shocking and painful. 


There is the arc of the romance between senpai and Yuu, which for senpai seems to happen nearly at first sight. But with Yuu's reluctance to open herself to love, it is a rather one sided romance for most of the story. Even at the very end Yuu tells herself she isn't in love when her actions clearly say otherwise. This is less a yuri romance than it is a special relationship between two girls driving their self discovery. Think much less Asagao to Kase-san and much more Citrus like. 


The story moves through an arc of self discovery, understanding and acceptance, which I found as a wonderful message that should be shared with the world over. If we learned the lessons our characters learned in this series, we would all be better people for it, and by extension, the world itself I would love to believe would be all the improved by it. I strive myself to remember these lessons now that I've seen them in series like this and other forms of media, so that perhaps I can help brighten the world, if only in the smallest manner. As I finished this series, these are the kinds of thoughts triggered by what I have seen, which I believe speak well to the quality of the story in general. 


Art: 9

The series is really good looking. The eyes were duly expressive, and each character was easily identified, even in situations where they were not in their standard clothes/hairstyles. The lines were cleaner and simpler than some anime series, but the overall artwork matched the themes and feelings invoked very well, so they earn high marks from me. 


Sound: 7 

To explain the knock, both the opening and closing themes were pretty, and the standard fare one would expect for a romance based title. I just did not find that either theme had any ear catching qualities. They did their job, and were pretty enough, but just not moving in the sense that say, the opening of Aoi Hana has. It was serviceable, but I don't find myself going back to listen to the songs alone like I do with many other anime. The voices are well done however, and everyone sounds appropriate. My only complaint was the themes themselves, everything else is well done. 


Character: 10

I have already spoken at length about senpai and her character in the story section, and I will elaborate a little more here. Her character is just absolutely painfully beautiful to take in as the series concludes. She might seem bland at first, but before it was done I had become misty eyed more than once due to her circumstances and motivation. She also struck a chord with me in that her feelings seemed genuine. I think if I was in her position I would feel, and act in the same manner she does. This to me speaks to how well thought out her character truly is. 


Yuu as a main character is interesting in that we see her growth as well, it's just a bit less pronounced. She's on a journey to discover who she is, and even who others around her are, especially senpai, though she does so with a little more subtlety than other characters. She learns about herself through observing others, and even though she holds out seemingly to the very end, I believe the ending makes it clear that she has grown in character as well, and has come to experience the very thing she thought she was never going to have. I think she learns, and we with her, that sometimes life events come to us in ways we don't expect. Sometimes we're looking for a gentle breeze and instead get hit by a train. Other times we're expecting a hurricane and instead are introduced via the whisper of a child. Now in both those situations the event, emotion, or situation may later have all the impact and importance in the world, but sometimes they just arrive in a manner we're not expecting. I believe Yuu experiences this very event. 


There is another character, a blonde that loves senpai, but is ultimately left out that is my only real holdout character wise. She's a bit aggressive in protecting her turf, even though senpai has not agreed to be with her romantically. She's so obviously in love with senpai that when an underclassman writes a play, she writes two characters romantically linked with senpai and blondie in mind specifically. Kind of an open secret. Blondie of course is not a Yuu fan, but this serves to provide a bit of an antagonist for the series. The point I have with blondie that I make a deduction for, is that in the ending she's shown as being relatively at peace, as though we're to think that in the end she's fine with everything without a level of growth that would warrant such acceptance. I think for her the best ending would have been one like Tamao from Strawberry Panic suffered in regards to Nagisa, that of support, but yet still a bit forlorn for what they can never have. 


Once the story begins turning and showing us new angles on our characters, we find a depth I don't think is very often discovered, whether it be in anime, television, or even movies. Usually one has to turn to written literature for such character depth. 


Enjoyment: 9

I will admit around episode 3 and 4, possibly even 5, I was slightly worried that this thing was never going to come together but how wrong I was. I think I now have a new favorite to throw on the old 'great shows' list. For me, once I found out senpai's motivation for her actions, I was in love. Again I fell when I got to the point where she reveals how she feels about herself. This may not be Aoi Hana, but boy did it get close for me, and if you have read any of my reviews you know how much Fumi has my heart. I will remember this series for a very long time. 


There you have it, if you don't mind a slow start, and taking in a bit of character building before the movement really gets started, you really can't go wrong here. This is a love story but more so a story of how love helps the girls learn and grow in their own lives. It's not the girls that move the romance, it's the romance that facilitates the girls' growing up. You better believe senpai and Yuu made the Great RTLR wall of anime goodness! All three thumbs up! (what you don't have three thumbs?)

This is probably the best series I have seen that I would never recommened to anyone. That might sound strange, so let me explain.
This series is pretty good. Some might even say fantastic. And that in pretty much every aspect. The characters feel real and believable, The animation ranges from good to breathtaking and the story/main relationship is very well handled.
The reason I would still never recommend this series to anyone despite all of its amazing atributes is one simple fact: It doesn't end, it simply stops. Now, being an adaptation of a still ongoing manga, that is nothing out ofthe ordinary and has happened with many other series as well. However, it is a bit different in this case.


The main bulk of the series' second half focuses on the play the student council is preparing for the culture festival. This play is the obvious emotional climax that the feelings of every single character are building towards. Touko feels that she has to do the play for her sister, but is also unsure whether the sister she knew even existed. Yuu wants to help Touko by means of the play, but also wants attention for herself. It is clear that this play will be a very important turning point in the narrative. However, the anime never gets to that point, rendering the second half of the series effectively pointless unlike other shows with incomplete endings which most of the time stop at the end of an arc, not in the middle of one.


To conclude, if anyone were to ask me whether or not I'd recommend them this series, I happily point them towards the manga instead. It has the same story and will actually finish it one day, which does not seem likely with the anime at this moment. However, even if a continuation were to be released one day, it wouldn't change the fact that the series was originally supposed to end without any conclusion.
